Entries.default:
The lighthouse is quiet but for soft, sibilant whispers. There's a repetitive, incantatory quality to them.

Yet as you cross the threshold, an old n훮ga with skin like cracked leather breaks off. He swivels to face you, baring one broken fang.
"If you joined them in befouling the adra, then you will join them in death, too."
"The sea-striped fiends send you to uproot the tree of the gods, yes? Their blasphemy knows no bounds!"

"Give the order, captain. Or just nod. I'm not picky." 

Maia's upper lip pulls back in a grimace.
The creatures hiss and advance on you, fangs bared.

"Go! Carry a warning of what you have seen to the other shufflers."

His tongue whips from his mouth like a ripped streamer.
"They died honorably. Show some respect."
"Quiet, both of you. I'm not here to yammer about a bunch of corpses."
"You're telling me this slaughter is all about adra?"
[Attack] "I've heard enough."
"I need to approach the adra."
[Leave] "I'll be going now."
He hisses. "Fool! See what the impiety of the sea-striped fiends has wrought!"
"Now, the gods return to rain their punishment on these islands. Again." His pupils narrow to angry slits.

The n훮ga stare at the glowing adra, their diamond pupils wide.

Sugaan turns his gaze to you, his body in a cautious half-coil.
[Attack] "No one stands in my way."
"I'm a Watcher. I can restore the adra if you'll just let me near it."
"Your stench is bitter on my tongue, shuffler. Why do you return?"
"Yes. Tell the other shufflers of the destruction that awaits."
[Pull Yanass' soul into the Here.] "Hear this, Sugaan."

Yanass' bright, wispy form appears, and the other n훮ga pull themselves into tight, fearful knots.

Only Sugaan cranes himself forward, his head cocked.
"Approach. Restore the blessing of the gods to the adra."
"You're saying the gods have brought ruin on Deadfire before?"
He bares his broken fang in surprise.
"Do your stories say nothing of the many disasters? Of the shuffler nests washed away like foam?"

"Many generations ago, the sand-striped ones built great hives across the islands. And bastions around the adra roots."

At this, the others hiss angrily.
"Their meddling displeased the gods. So the gods smashed their works with heaving volcanoes and crashing waves." His beads and bangles rattle as he brings his hands together in a loud clap.
"The gods see. They will tear them all down."
"Our ancestors hid deep, where the waters quenched the fires and muffled the storms. They remembered while shufflers scattered."
"Eothas came to reach the adra, not to punish anyone."
"Lies and treachery! The gods do not wither their own roots." He recoils.
"Sugaan! I found the way!" Emotion pulses through her essence, crackling in the ether.
[Background: Nihilist] "Kith and wilder have always fought. There's no meaning in any of it."

As the last of Yanass' essence fades back into the In-Between, Sugaan regards the adra vein, calculation flickering in his eyes.

At last, he turns his guarded gaze on you.
"How could you know this?"
"So you think history is repeating itself."
"Now, the shufflers build again." He thumps his tail on the floorboards.
"You cast off your sheddings by night only to put them back on at daybreak. You wrap yourself in filthy, worn-out things." A tremor of disgust ripples through his body.
"What's the Deep Hunter?"
"The defender of the isles. The guardian of tides." He makes a reverent gesture.
"Once it lived among us. In all bright, quiet places where shufflers did not go."

"But then more came from distant lands. First few, then many.

"Now, our Deep Hunter is gone." He glares at you as though you're to blame.
"Berath sent me. I'm here doing the will of the gods."
His tail whips on the ground as he considers you.
"So! The fiends corrupt even the sand-striped ones. Now I taste their stench on her."
"Long have we kept peace with the sand-striped people."
"We must go. I know not what this means, but our brethren should hear of it."

He bows. "You show us something new today, shuffler. Thank you for this.

"And for your mercy."

He presses something into your palm before departing.
"Slaughter is never a holy mission."
"That's because they killed your people and took your land. They see everything differently."
"What now?"
"But on whose terms?" His tail flicks in irritation.

"Perhaps not. I see Berath's mark on this one." He regards your head and its warped flesh.

His tongue flickers.
"If this is not some fat-tongued lie, then show us."
[Cast Blessing.] "I call on the gods, and they listen. Do not test me - or the gods - further."

He and the other n훮ga recoil, hissing their amazement. 

At last, Sugaan straightens and regards you with a wary eye.
"Heal the adra, shuffler. If you can."

"This you said before. And still you returned.

"We cannot trust your thick-tongued lies."
"Another sea-striped fiend, here to uproot the tree of the gods!"
His head twitches in her direction, his tongue flickering.

"Your sand-striped kind knew better. Once, you left these roots to grow. 

"As the gods intended."
"The sand-striped shufflers know better. But you others come - smooth-toned or furred or sea-striped - with blasphemous hunger."
"Now, foreign ones dig at these roots, and the Deep Hunter is with us no more."
"Now, you let foreign fiends dig at these roots. They drive the Deep Hunter away."
"The tree of the gods, yes! Which these fiends plunder and profane."
"What 'warning' do you expect me to deliver?"

"That shufflers must not disturb these roots. Or the gods will destroy the islands again."

The other n훮ga hiss in agreement.
"Go on."
"'Sand-striped' - you're describing the Huana."
Letting out a deep sigh, Tek휆hu raises a hand to touch his brow.
"Huana civilization spanned the archipelago, but the Engwithans built temples around the adra."

He hisses. "They did not build alone! The sand-striped ones helped.

"As they help other fiends now."
He eyes Maia coldly.
[Attack] "I've heard enough."
"If your fat tongue speaks true, then give us proof."
"What would you consider proof?"
"I tell you, thick tongues lie. Forked tongues do not."
"If what you say is true, then surely you can speak with the dead." He cocks his head to appraise you with one eye.
"I will believe your words only if I hear them from the tongue of my own people."
"You shufflers are beasts of habit. You do not learn. You do not change."

"The way became dark. But this [player race] brought light." She turns briefly to you.

But Sugaan's mouth is rigid in a broken-fanged grimace.
"Hsst! We will kill the shuffler and free your soul, Yanass."

"Do old scales cloud your eyes? The [player race] glows. Like the god-walker.

"Like the way." She looks toward the dull adra vein. Sugaan and the others follow her gaze.

"He will open the way."

Yanass points to you just as she begins to disappear.
Entries.female:
"She will open the way."

Yanass points to you just as she begins to disappear.

Entries.default: "Yanass? You died. We saw-"
"I'm standing right here..."
"Just listen to her, Sugaan."
"It doesn't work that way."
"I'm trying to help!"
"I'll free YOUR soul if you try, snake."
Yanass turns to Sugaan, hissing angrily.
"Their ancestors, yes!"
"The shuffler's tongue is thick with blasphemy! Kill him now, Sugaan." The other n훮ga draws into a tight coil as if preparing to strike.
Entries.female: "The shuffler's tongue is thick with blasphemy! Kill her now, Sugaan." The other n훮ga draws into a tight coil as if preparing to strike.

Entries.default: "The gods give you power, yes. But is it enough?"
"The proof, you reptilian imbecile, is that I have bested your minions. Alone."
Sugaan regards you with a wary eye.

"And do not come back. Not without proof the gods have blessed you."

The n훮ga watch you go, their hands tight around their weapons.

"And do not come back."

The n훮ga watch you, their hands tight around their weapons.
"We were sure the god-walker came to cast them out. That driving them away was a holy mission." Curiosity and consternation simmer in his eyes.
"But then the foreign ones came and spread. Killed our people. Built their hives everywhere."
"Good neighbors, I say. As long as we do not cross paths in mating season."
"Sci챵derie. You attack every foreign ship you see. The Huana may not like us, but at least they speak to us."
"Your type weren't exactly accommodating."

"You have never fought to defend something. Very fortunate.

"Or cowardly." His tail flicks in irritation.
"Shufflers find many stories to explain their hunger and violence." His tail flicks in irritation.
"The gods have bigger concerns than our feuds. We must learn to live together."
"There's no point in speculating about the will of the gods."
"You should be driving them out. You just didn't hit them hard enough."

"Not an option, snake. Bet you were keeping count of how many good soldiers you fanged." 

Maia narrows her eyes and draws her weapon.
"As you wish, Maia."
"And now he owes us. A debt is more useful than blood."
"There's been too much death here already."
[Attack] "You're right. We shall avenge your fallen."
"Killing him won't bring them back."

"Vengeance for my countrymen!" 

Maia lets out a rallying cry.
"Let it go."
[Attack] "That wouldn't be any fun."
"That is the answer of idlers and tenderbellies too weak of purpose to crawl from their own shed skin." His tail flicks in irritation.
"I hope your leaders find your strength of purpose." He gives you a respectful nod.
"This was but a single battle. The islands are many and treacherous, shuffler."
"Hsst! Thoughts as empty as shed skins."
"They have received their due. As will all who plunder and profane the treasure of the gods!"
"Then leave!"
"Who are these 'shufflers' you keep mentioning?"
He hisses with impatience.
"Your kind! Many different types, some fleshy or hairy, others striped in the colors of sand or sea."
"All stumble and shamble like sun-blind hatchlings."
"That sounds like the gods, all right."
"The gods are more than spiteful juggernauts, you know."

"They lie coiled, quiet, until the shufflers stumble where they should not.

"Then, they strike fast and fierce."
"Yes, for all they do has purpose."
"The gods summon storms. Call down moons. If they wanted Hasongo destroyed, they would not have left a single stone standing."
"Adra is not a root that withers, but a channel of essence. This one is merely blocked - I can show you."
"Adra is not a root that withers, but a channel of essence. This one is merely blocked - I can show you."
"Get to the point already. What do you want?"
[Look up.] "Berath, this would be a great time for one of your demonstrations..."
Nothing happens. The n훮ga continue to watch you, curious.

"Captain?" 

Maia turns to you, her right eye twitching.
"Vengeance won't save the ones you lost, soldier."
"Just kidding. I could use some snakeskin gloves."
"Stand down. That's an order."
"Pace yourself. We have more important fights ahead of us."
Gritting her teeth, Maia secures her weapon and stands down, her fists balled at her sides.
"Aye aye... sir."

"Wherever we sail, the beaches and spires of lost Ukaizo travel with us."

He clasps his hands with reverence.
